The effect of synthesis temperature on the particle size of nano-ZIF-8 Chih-Wei Tsai, Ernie H.G. Langner* Department of Chemistry, University of the Free State, Nelson Mandela Drive, P.O. Box 339, Bloemfontein 9300, South Africa, langneeh@ufs.ac.za
Abstract The particle size and size distribution of Zeolitic Imidazole Framework-8 (ZIF-8) nanoparticles are influenced by the synthesis temperature during isothermal mixing reactions in methanol. As the synthesis temperature is increased from -15°C to 60°C, the average nanoparticle size decreased from 78 nm to 26 nm, with a simultaneous narrowing of the particle size distribution. Adsorption studies showed an increase in the external surface area of the nanoparticles from 220 m² g-1 till 336 m² g-1 as the particle size decreases from 78 nm till 26 nm. The increased external surface area of ZIF-8 nanoparticles (nZIF-8) led to a significantly higher catalytic activity when compared to the catalytic activity of commercially available ZIF-8 micro-particles in a Knoevenagel condensation test reaction.
Keywords ZIF-8 nanoparticles, isothermal synthesis, particle size, catalytic activity
1. Introduction Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks (ZIFs), a subclass of porous metal organic frameworks (MOFs), first reported in 2006, have a unique bonding angle of 145° between the metal and the imidazolate linker (M-Im-M angle), mimicking the Si-O-Si
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
2
angle of zeolites. ZIF-8 has a porous polymeric network structure made up from zinc metal centres tetrahedrally coordinated to 2-methylimidazole ligands, giving a SOD (Sodalite) topology with a surface area of ~1600 m2 g-1 and a six-ring pore aperture of 3.4 Å. ZIF-8 has a high thermal stability up to 400 °C [1]. ZIF-8 has potential application in gas storage or separation [2], drug delivery [3] and chemical sensing [4]. According to DFT calculations, the external surface of ZIF-8 not only has Lewis acid and basic sites, but also Brønsted acid sites. These active sites are not present on the internal surface of the pores [5]. ZIF-8 is known to catalyse reactions such as the Knoevenagel condensation [6], transesterification [5] and Friedel Craft acylation [7]. These reactions were all performed using micro-sized ZIF-8, which is available commercially as Basolite Z1200® by BASF, and obtained through a solvothermal process. When micro-sized (100 to 200 µm) ZIF-8 particles were employed as heterogeneous catalyst for the Knoevenagel reaction between benzaldehyde and malononitrile at room temperature in toluene, the reaction was catalysed exclusively on the external surface of ZIF-8, with the smaller particles exhibiting a higher catalytic activity than the larger particles [6,8]. ZIF-8 nanocrystals (nZIF-8) can be synthesized by mixing of the reactants at ambient conditions in methanol [9]. Crystal growth of ZIF-8 in methanol can be divided into three processes: Nucleation, crystal growth and a stationary phase [10]. Slow nucleation occurs together with fast crystal growth [11], during which the 2-methyl imidazole reagent can act as a linker unit when deprotonated or as a stabilizing unit when neutral [12]. Deprotonation of the 2-methylimidazole ligand with a base provides a faster nucleation rate, resulting in smaller crystals [11]. Control of particle size and particle size distribution is important since it will influence the external surface area available for catalysis. Surfactants and polymers have been
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3
used as additives to assist in particle size control during ZIF-8 synthesis, resulting in a high yield and particle sizes of 200 to 400 nm [13]. Smaller particles of around 200 nm and a yield of 85 % were obtained during pH-adjusted sonocrystallization reactions [14]. Nanoparticles smaller than 100 nm were synthesized by a rapid room-temperature colloidal reaction in methanol, with a ratio of 1:8:700 for Zn2+, 2-methylimidazole and methanol respectively. With XRD peak broadening a particle size of 46 nm was determined and with SEM and HRTEM a size of 40 nm [12]. By the addition of 1 % high molecular weight (Mw 400 000 - 500 000) poly(diallyl-dimethylammonium chloride) polymer to the nZIF-8 reaction mixture in methanol, a very narrow size distribution with an average particle size of 57 nm was obtained [15]. Addition of nbutylamine to the reaction mixture in methanol at room temperature in different ratios, gave particle sizes between 9 to 55 nm [11]. Methanol gives the best yields and product purity, but other polar solvents such as DMF or water, may also be used to synthesize nanoparticles of ZIF-8 [16]. In water, nZIF-8 was synthesized at room temperature to obtain particles with an average size of 85 nm in 80 % yield [17]. A spray drying/EISA (Evaporated Induced Self Assembly) technique using a mixture of methanol and water produced nZIF-8 with a particle size ~100 nm [18]. Other methods to promote the formation of smaller particles make use of surfactants as capping agents during which the hydrophobic hydrocarbon chains of the surfactant absorbed on the ZIF-8 surface hinders the reagents attachment to the surface thus slowing down the growth rate of the crystals [19]. A technique using surfactant-stabilized water-in-oil emulsions (Brij® reverse micelle systems) to control the particle size of as-synthesized ZIF-8 nanoparticles resulted in particles of 30-160 nm with a very narrow size distribution. Decreasing the temperature of the system from 50°C to 37°C and reducing the precursor

concentration by half, gave particle sizes smaller than 30 nm [8]. Here we report on the effect of synthesis temperature on the formation of ZIF-8 nanoparticles (nZIF-8) in methanol, without the use of any additives. We also demonstrate that nanoparticles of ZIF-8 have a significantly higher catalytic activity in a Knoevenagel test reaction than the micro-sized ZIF-8. Except for its high extinction coefficient in the UV/vis spectral region, we chose Ferrocenecarboxaldehyde as reagent since it is larger than the largest pore window of ZIF-8 [20 ], effectively preventing its migration into the pores.
2. Experimental 2.1. Materials and Equipment Reagents (Sigma-Aldrich) and solvents (Merck) were used without further purification unless stated otherwise. Double distilled water was used where necessary. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed with a Philips (FEI) CM100 equipped with a Megaview III digital camera and coupled to an Oxford X-Max (80 mm2), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDS). TEM pictures were analysed utilizing Soft Imaging System (analySIS) software. All infrared spectra were measured on a Bruker Tensor 27 infrared spectrophotometer fitted with a Pike Miracle single bounce diamond ATR crystal or A Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 ATR Infrared Spectrometer. UV/vis spectra were measured on a Shimadzu UV-1650 PC UV-Visible spectrophotometer fitted with a 6 cell attachment and a Shimadzu CPS-240A temperature controller. All porosity and surface area measurements were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Surface Area and Porosity Analyser. Porosity results were refined by MicroActive V1.01 Software. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) were collected on a Bruker D2 Phaser powder X-ray diffractometer at room

2.2. Synthesis of nZIF-8 at various temperatures in methanol All nZIF-8 batches were synthesized (isothermally at 7 different temperatures, Table 1) by the following adapted general procedure, described for 25ºC [12]. A solution of Zn(NO3)2.4H2O (0.649 g, 2.48 mmol) in methanol (50 cm 3) at 25oC was rapidly added to a solution of 2-methylimidazole (1.643 g, 19.99 mmol) in methanol (50 cm3) at 25ºC. The mixture was stirred for 1 hour at 25ºC. The precipitate was isolated by centrifugation (7000 rpm, 30 min, 15 oC), washed with methanol (3 x 100 cm3), isolated by centrifugation and dried in air overnight. After activation at 250oC under nitrogen flow for 90 minutes the product was obtained as a white powder. For the purpose of TEM measurements and catalytic test reactions, stable dispersions of nZIF-8 in methanol or THF were prepared through sonication (1 min at 175 W using a sonic probe and 5 min in a sonic bath).
2.3. Bulk Synthesis of 1,1-Dicyano-2-ferrocenylethene with nZIF-8 as catalyst Ferrocenecarboxaldehyde (0.407 g, 1.9 mmol) was dissolved and nZIF-8 (0.02 g, 0.087 mmol) dispersed in tetrahydrofuran (THF) (4 cm3). Malononitrile (0.379 g, 5.74 mmol) was dissolved in THF (1 cm3). Both solutions were heated to 50ºC before mixing them in a closed container. The reaction was stirred overnight and turned to dark purple. The crude product was purified with column chromatography (hexane:ether 1:1 on silica)

2.4. Time resolved synthesis of 1,1-Dicyano-2-ferrocenylethene with nZIF-8 as catalyst The Knoevenagel condensation reaction at 50ºC between ferrocenecarboxaldehyde and malononitrile (1:1 molar ratio) in THF was monitored by a change in absorbance at 570 nm. Small aliquots were removed at regular time intervals from the reactant mixture, diluted 1000 times with cold (3ºC) THF to quench the reaction and immediately recorded on a UV/Vis spectrophotometer. This process was repeated for the reaction without catalyst, with commercial (micro-sized) ZIF-8 (4.35 mole %) and with nZIF-8 (4.35 mole %) as catalyst (Supplementary Material, S.1).
3. Results and discussion To control the particle size, seven isothermal syntheses between -15 °C and 60 °C with a set ratio of Zn2+:2-methylimidazole (MeIM):Methanol of 1:8:1000 were performed in triplicate (Scheme 1). The maximum temperature of 60 °C was chosen to prevent the evaporation of methanol and avoid reflux conditions.

All the nZIF-8 products were characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) as well as Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The IR spectra of all nZIF-8 batches are identical to that of commercial ZIF-8 (Basolite Z1200®, Supplementary Material, S.2 and S.3). The PXRD spectra of nZIF-8 synthesized at 60 ºC (a) (Figure 1) matches the PXRD pattern of Basolite Z1200®, (b), as well as the simulated spectrum, (c). This is also true for all the other nZIF-8 products (Supplementary Material, S.4). From the well-defined PXRD patterns it can be concluded that the synthesized nZIF-8 particles are highly crystalline with SOD (Sodalite) topologies, showing that synthesis temperature has no influence on the structure.
Figure 1 PXRD patterns of nZIF-8 synthesized at a) 60 ºC (blue) b) Basolite Z1200® (commercial ZIF-8, red) and c) simulated ZIF-8 (black). The Miller-indices of the first six signals are indicated at (a).
When comparing the PXRD peaks of nZIF-8 (a in Figure 1) to that of the Basolite Z1200® (commercial ZIF-8, b in Figure 1), a slight broadening of the peaks is observed due to the nano crystalline nature of the nZIF-8. The minimum average crystalline size was observed to decrease as the synthesis temperature was increased. A decrease of ca. 33 % was observed for the minimum particle size of nZIF-8 synthesized at -15 ºC, compared to those synthesized at 60 ºC. In terms of average TEM particle size, the decrease was ca. 65 %. A direct measurement of the particle sizes and size distributions of nZIF-8 synthesized at different temperatures is given by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images, as seen in Figure 2 where the images and histograms for -15 °C (a), 25 °C (b) and 60 °C (c) are displayed. Those for the other synthesis temperatures can be found in the Supplementary Material, S.5 – S.9.

With an increase in synthesis temperature from -15°C to 60°C, the TEM measurements shows a decrease in average particle size of ca. 65 % (from ~78 nm to ~27 nm). Simultaneously, the size distribution also decreased from a 78 nm difference (at -15 °C) between the maximum and minimum particle size to a 24 nm difference (at 60 °C) (Figure 3). As reported earlier, the synthesis of nZIF-8 consists of slow nucleation accompanied by fast crystal growth [11] In this study it was found that the size of nZIF-8 nanoparticles decreased as the synthesis temperature increased. This can be explained by visualizing that faster nucleation at high synthesis temperatures leads to a higher concentration of nanoparticles. At low temperatures nucleation is slowed down. This results in fewer nucleating particles which can grow larger in the presence of an abundance of starting material. We conclude that the rate of nucleation is dependent on synthesis temperature. Accelerated surface area and porosity analyses (ASAP) with N2 at 77 K, produced similar N2 isotherms for all the nZIF-8 batches synthesized from -15 °C till 60 °C (Supplementary Material, Figure S.10 – S.16), with BET surface areas between ~1625 m² g-1 and 1820 m² g-1. These obtained surface areas correspond well with the BET surface area of commercial ZIF-8 (1672 m² g-1) (Table 1). A general trend between particle size and external surface area was observed for the nZIF-8 particles synthesized at different temperatures. The measured isotherms’ thickness curves (t-plots), utilizing the Harkins and Jura thickness approximation, shows that the external surface areas of the smaller nZIF-8 particles are larger than the external surface areas of the larger

The time-based reaction profiles (Figure 5, insert), obtained from these measurements, shows that with the use of well-dispersed nano-sized ZIF-8 as catalyst, the reaction proceeds at a significantly faster rate in the first 100 hours (top curve, red), than the reaction catalysed by micro-sized ZIF-8 (Basolite Z1200®) (middle curve, blue). Without a catalyst, no product formation was detected (bottom curve, green) at 50°C. The turnover frequencies (TOF’s) calculated for the first 25 h of the reactions were found to be 0.16 h-1 and 0.40 h-1 for commercial micro sized ZIF-8 (Basolite Z1200®) and our nZIF-8 respectively (Calculations: Supplementary Material, S.17). This represents a 2.5 fold increase in TOF from micro sized ZIF-8 to nano sized ZIF-8, which correlates well with the 2.9 fold increase in the t-plot external surface area from micro (116 m2 g-1) to nano sized ZIF-8 (336 m2 g-1). The observed increase in TOF number, which parallels the increase in external surface area, serves as further

4. Conclusions In this study, particle size control of nano sized ZIF-8 (between 26 and 78 nm) was successfully achieved by applying different synthesis temperatures (-15, -5, 2, 25, 40, 50 and 60°C) during simple bench top isothermal reactions in methanol. Real particle size distributions were determined by statistical measurement of TEM pictures, while the Scherrer equation was applied to PXRD data peak broadening to calculate minimum particle sizes. TEM analyses have shown that a synthesis temperature of -15°C gave, on average 78 nm nZIF-8 particles with a wider particle size distribution than the smaller diameter particles (26 nm) formed at 60°C. The PXRD results, giving minimum particle sizes, were in agreement with the results from TEM measurements. Porosity measurements showed that nZIF-8 particles of all sizes are capable of adsorbing more than 400 cm3 g-1 of N2 (STP) at 77 K, with BET surface areas of more than 1600 m 2 g-1. The external surface area of the nanoparticles was calculated for each batch using t-plot analysis and found to be increasing from 220 to 336 m2 g-1 as the particle size decreases. The smallest nanoparticles, synthesized at 60 °C, have an external surface area 2.9 times that of the commercial ZIF-8 (116 m2 g-1). During the catalytic application of these nZIF-8 particles, a 2.5 fold increase in turnover frequency, during the Knoevenagel condensation reaction between ferrocenecarboxaldehyde and malononitrile, was achieved, compared to micro sized commercial ZIF-8. The increased external surface area of the nZIF-8 is thus a direct cause for the increased turnover frequency observed.

metadata.abstractText: The particle size and size distribution of Zeolitic Imidazole Framework-8 (ZIF-8) nanoparticles are influenced by the synthesis temperature during isothermal mixing reactions in methanol. As the synthesis temperature is increased from -15°C to 60°C, the average nanoparticle size decreased from 78 nm to 26 nm, with a simultaneous narrowing of the particle size distribution. Adsorption studies showed an increase in the external surface area of the nanoparticles from 220 m2 g till 336 m2 g as the particle size decreases from 78 nm till 26 nm. The increased external surface area of ZIF-8 nanoparticles (nZIF-8) led to a significantly higher catalytic activity when compared to the catalytic activity of commercially available ZIF-8 micro-particles in a Knoevenagel condensation test reaction.
